arch:property.oc:show_val: This is a surface on the north side of the old wall foundation, L155. It stretches from the west corner to the east corner, goes to the north and west baulk, and ends at the wall that is L155 and L158. It is fill, with many rock and artifact inclusions. A few pottery sherds lie flat, indicating that it is possibly a surface. The north corner has what appears to be an ash layer. The west corner seems possibly to be a separate surface because it has a different appearance to it. Nearer the east corner is what seems to be an increase in artifacts. These are all the same locus, however, unless/until they become very different during excavation. In the end the ashy corner became its own locus, 159, and the northwest corner became its own locus as well, L162. The dividing line between this locus and L159 is not clear, meaning that material classified as belonging to one locus could actually belong to the other. This is something to consider when looking at either loci. Additionally, these loci are similar enough that it does not make much of a diffeerence. Upon the closing of the locus, a surface consisting of smooth stones was found that spread throughout most of the locus. Additionally, this locus produced a high concentration of bone and Ubaid pottery. It was determined that this locus was indeed a fill between two Ubaid surfaces.

arch:note.arch:string: Contexts excavated in trenches were recorded using the "locus system." A locus is any discrete three-dimensional entity excavated in a trench. The key to the locus system is the recognition that a locus is any one thing. Differences in soil composition or texture are therefore as important as, for example, the difference between a pit and a wall. If two entities were distinct, they were considered separate loci and were therefore assigned separate locus numbers. It should also be noted that every context excavated in a trench was given a locus number and thus the trench itself is made up completely of excavated loci.

oc:metadata.dc:title: Kenan Tepe: Area E / Trench 2 / Locus 156 (Locus)
